Mass. House passes
three-strikes bill

The measure would eliminate parole for habitual criminal offenders while reducing some mandatory minimum sentences for nonviolent drug offenders.
Opinion | Yvonne Abraham

Not a race matter

Carol Johnson made a grievous error in failing to discipline a headmaster charged with domestic assault. Casting her woes in racial terms is too easy.

Parents helping fill summer-job void

Summer jobs for teenagers have become a precious commodity, and some parents — desperate for their kids to have work — are stepping in.
Opinion | Bob Ryan

Should Penn State sack football?

The school needs to shut the football program down for two years, and rethink why it exists.

A new look at old Gloucester

A 1.2-mile loop, which includes a virtual tour that can be downloaded onto a smartphone, brings to light previously hard-to-find historical and cultural lore.

Workers fuel flight of firms to the city

To draw young talent, firms are moving from the suburbs into urban neighborhoods with convenient public transit and a lively food and bar scene.

College for working women faces
closure over deficit of $250,000

The Urban College of Boston, which educates 600 women from low-income and immigrant backgrounds, is on the ropes.
